metadata.title: Thousands of New York MH professionals volunteer for service

body_text.text: Many of the mental health professionals are volunteering beyond their regular scope of business, while others have retired and are volunteering their time as clinicians, said Glenn Liebman, CEO of the Mental Health Association in New York State (MHANYS). “It speaks to the calling of people in our field to go above and beyond supporting people during this crisis,” Liebman told MHW.

“It's important that mental health is being discussed at the highest level of government,” said Liebman, adding that it's important that people's concerns related to anxiety, depression and substance abuse are being recognized.

“It's a credit to the state and nationally that these issues have been addressed and are understood like never before,” Liebman said. While MHANYS is not directly involved in staffing the hotline, when the organization sees people in need of care, they are directed to the call center.

He pointed to Vibrant Emotional Health, formerly the Mental Health Association in New York City, which spearheads the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline. If necessary, consumers with mental health issues have been referred there, he said.

While the first three stimulus packages have been helpful, Liebman said he hopes the next stimulus package provides greater, specific resources for mental health and human resources to support “essential people who are on the front line in the war against the coronavirus.”
MHANYS intends to work with national organizations, such as Mental Health America, to make that message a clear part of the stimulus package, he said.
